revision.text:
{{recent|date=June 2012}}
The '''New Jersey Redistricting Commission''' is a [[New Jersey State Constitution|constitutional]] body of the [[government]] of New Jersey tasked with redrawing the state's Congressional election districts after each decade's census. Like [[Arizona]], [[Idaho]], [[Hawaii]], [[Montana]], and [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]; the [[redistricting]] is completed within an independent, [[bipartisan]] commission. The apportionment of members of the Redistricting Commission is carefully balanced between legislative and executive majorities and is purposefully titled to allow the minority party an equal amount of seats on the commission. [[File:NJ 109th congressional districts shaded by party.png|right|thumb|New Jersey congressional districts.]] Note that this commission deals with districts for the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] while the [[New Jersey Apportionment Commission]] deals with legislative districts for the [[New Jersey Legislature]].
According to the state Constitution, New Jersey's commission has 13 members. The President of the Senate and Assembly Speaker each name two members; the minority leaders of both houses each name two members and the state's Democratic and Republican chairpersons each name two members. The 12 members then select a 13th "tie-breaking" member to chair of the commission. If they cannot agree on the 13th member, then each party submits a name to the state's [[New Jersey Supreme Court|Supreme Court]], which chooses one as the 13th member.
The commission is required to hold three public meetings, but is otherwise allowed to meet in private until it releases its new map.<ref name="NJconst">[[s:New Jersey Constitution of 1947|New Jersey Constitution of 1947]]. Article II, Section 2</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.njredistrictingcommission.org/aboutredistricting.asp|title=NJ Redistricting Commission|accessdate=2011-12-29|publisher=NJ Redistricting Commission}}</ref>
==2012 - 2021 Congressional Map== Following the [[2010 United States Census|2010 Census]], New Jersey lost one of its 13 seats in Congress.<ref>{{cite news |title=N.J. loses seat in Congress as Census Bureau unveils population numbers |url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2010/12/nj_to_lose_seat_in_congress_af.html |work=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=Dec. 21, 2010 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref>
The commission named former Attorney General [[John Farmer, Jr.]] as its tiebreaking member.<ref>{{cite news |title=Farmer ready to serve as 13th member as commission set to certify his selection|url=http://www.politickernj.com/49669/farmer-ready-serve-13th-member-commission-set-certify-his-selection |work=PolitickerNJ.com |date=July 18, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref> Earlier in the year, Farmer had been counsel to the [[New Jersey Apportionment Commission]].
On December 23 the commission chose a map endorsed by Republican members, which combined [[New Jersey's 5th congressional district]], represented by [[Scott Garrett|Rep. Scott Garrett]], with part of the [[New Jersey's 9th congressional district|9th congressional district]], held by [[Steve Rothman|Rep. Steve Rothman]].<ref>{{cite news |title=N.J. committee assigned to redraw congressional districts submit final proposals |url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/12/nj_committee_assigned_to_redra.html |work=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=Dec. 22, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=New map sets stage for battle in 5th District |url=http://www.njherald.com/story/16390169/redrawn-fifth-district-could-set-battleground |work=[[New Jersey Herald]] |date=Dec. 27, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=N.J.'s new congressional map gives edge to GOP |url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-12-24/news/30554845_1_new-congressional-map-congressional-district-boundaries-democrats |work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=Dec. 24, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref> Much of the balance of the 9th District was included in a redrawn [[New Jersey's 8th congressional district|8th Congressional District]], which is represented by [[William Pascrell|Rep. William Pascrell]].<ref>{{cite news |title=New Map Roils N.J. District |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=Dec. 28, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203479104577124980824542536.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=New Jersey tilts redistricting battle toward GOP |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/new-jersey-tilts-redistricting-battle-toward-gop/2011/12/27/gIQAHmEnKP_blog.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=Dec. 24, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref> Democratic members of the committee had also planned to pit Rothman against Garrett.<ref>{{cite news |title=Democrats' map reveals similar lines to GOP winner|url=http://www.politickernj.com/53475/democrats-map-reveals-similar-lines-gop-winner |work=PolitickerNJ.com |date=Dec. 23, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref>
Instead of challenging Garrett, on Dec. 26 Rothman announced a primary election challenge against Pascrell for the 8th District.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rep. Steve Rothman to challenge Rep. Bill Pascrell in June Democratic primary |url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/12/rep_steve_rothman_to_challenge.html |work=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=Dec. 27, 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref>
